resources.string: The number of training for 1 week
Stop putting it off for later, individual training is already waiting for you!
I agree with the conditions of service and the confidentiality policy

1. Freestyle (Front Crawl)

Features: The fastest swimming style, used in most competitions. Known for high efficiency and streamlining.

Technique:

Arms alternate in circular strokes forward, entering the water in front of the shoulder. After catching the water, the arm pulls under the body and recovers above the surface.

Legs perform quick and strong flutter kicks from the hips, with heels slightly breaking the surface.

Breathing — turn your head to the side during the arm recovery phase; avoid lifting it too high.

Tip:

- Keep your body elongated and straight.

- Use minimal effort for maximum glide.

- Coordinate arms, legs, and breathing smoothly.

2. Breaststroke


Features: The slowest but most stable stroke. Great for long-distance swimming and beginners learning technique.

Technique:

Arms move simultaneously forward, then sweep outwards and back to the chest.

Legs perform a frog kick — heels drawn to the hips, then pushed out and together.

Breathing — during the head lift at the start of the arm pull.

Tip:

- Maintain perfect synchronization of arm and leg movements.

- Pause briefly in a fully extended glide after each cycle.

- Focus on clean technique over speed.

3. Butterfly


Features: The most physically demanding style. Requires strength and flexibility, especially in the back and core.

Technique:

Arms move together in a wide pull: enter the water in front of the head, catch and push down and back.

Legs perform dolphin kicks — a fluid wave motion from the chest to the feet. Two kicks per arm cycle.

Breathing — raise your head after the main arm pull when the shoulders exit the water.

Tip:

- Drive the motion with your torso, not just the legs.

- Breathe rhythmically, ideally every cycle.

- Train back, shoulder, and core muscles outside the water as well.

4. Backstroke


Features: The only style swum on the back. Allows for free breathing but requires good navigation.

Technique:

Arms alternate, entering the water above the head and pulling along the side of the body to the hip.

Legs perform flutter kicks, similar to freestyle. Kicks should be steady and come from the hips.

Breathing — unrestricted, as the face remains above the water.

Tip:

- Look straight up or slightly back; avoid lifting your chin.

- Keep your arms close to the head during recovery.

- Use visual cues (ceiling or shore) to stay oriented.
